section.heading: Scope.
section.text: These regulations establish a science-based status assessment protocol to determine the harm and impact caused by invasive plants, including an approval procedure for activities involving invasive plant species that cause or are likely to cause severe harm and administrative orders that the Secretary may issue to enforce these regulations.

para.text: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.

“Classify as a prohibited invasive plant” means the Secretary is including an invasive plant on the Consolidated List of Maryland Invasive Plant Species in accordance with the Agriculture Article, §§9.5-301 and 9.5-301.1, Annotated Code of Maryland.
“Commercial entity” means an entity that engages in a plant removal activity for profit.
“Committee” means the Invasive Plants Advisory Committee.

“Consolidated List of Maryland Invasive Plant Species” means a list of plant species classified as prohibited invasive plants in accordance with Agriculture Article §§9.5-301 and 9.5-301.1, Annotated Code of Maryland.
“Early Detection Rapid Response (EDRR) Plant Species” means a nonnative plant species that:
Is not yet widespread in the State but is at risk of:
Becoming established as an invasive species; and
Causing significant damage; and
Has:
Been found in at least one native species habitat in the State; or
Not yet been found in the State.
“Expert Assessor” means:
An individual or a team within the Department or the Department of Natural Resources; or
A qualified independent assessor.
Invasive plant.

Invasive Plant means any living part of a plant species or its subspecies that did not evolve in the State and if introduced within the State, will cause or is likely to cause, as determined by the Secretary:
Economic harm;
Ecological harm;
Environmental harm; or
Harm to human health.
“Invasive plant” includes a commercial or noncommercial plant that is terrestrial or aquatic and meets the definition under §B(7)(a) of this regulation.

“Invasive Plant Species Status Assessment Protocol” means a protocol based on the NatureServe’s 2004 protocol (An Invasive Species Assessment Protocol: Evaluating Non-Native Plants for the Impact on Biodiversity. Version 1.)

“Invasiveness Rank” means a rank assigned to a nonnative species to signify its level of invasiveness (i.e., high, medium, low or insignificant) based on the results of an invasive assessment protocol.
“Landscaping services” includes services for ornamental horticultural design, maintenance, and installation of living plants.
“Prohibited invasive plant” includes invasive plant species that cause or are likely to cause severe harm within the State.
“Qualified independent assessor” means an individual or team that:

Possesses at least 2 years of field experience in invasive plant species in Maryland or in nearby jurisdictions, including Washington, D.C., Delaware, New Jersey, New York, Pennsylvania, Virginia, and West Virginia; and
Has assessed invasive plant species without supervision from the Department, the Department of Natural Resources or the Committee.
“Watch List” means a list of plant species that:
Have been assessed by an expert assessor in accordance with Agriculture Article, §9.5-301, Annotated Code of Maryland;
Were not determined by the assessment to be eligible for classification as a prohibited invasive plant; and
May be reassessed in the future.

section.heading: Invasive Plant Species Status Assessment Protocol.

para.text: The Secretary shall determine whether an invasive plant qualifies as a prohibited invasive plant or a plant for the Watch List based on the following protocol. An expert assessor shall complete a plant status assessment based on the NatureServe’s 2004 protocol (an invasive species assessment protocol: evaluating non-native plants for their impact on biodiversity. Version 1.)
Assessments completed by an expert assessor shall be reviewed and approved by the Invasive Plant Advisory Committee.

Except as approved by the Secretary under this regulation, a person may not propagate, import, transfer, sell, purchase, transport, or introduce any living part of a prohibited invasive plant in the State.
A person may conduct an activity prohibited under §A of this regulation if:
The person receives approval from the Secretary before conducting the activity; and
The activity is for the purpose of:
Disposing of the invasive plant;
Controlling the invasive plant;
Using the invasive plant for research or educational purposes; or
Exporting the invasive plant out of the State
A person has the Secretary’s approval and may engage in any activity prohibited by §A of this regulation for the limited purpose of:
Controlling a prohibited invasive plant, provided:
The person is not a commercial entity;
The plant is not taken off-site; and
The plant is not placed at a location in the proximate vicinity of a roadway or waterway that could facilitate the movement of the invasive plant off-site; or
Transporting a prohibited invasive plant off-site for the purpose of identification or disposal, provided:
The person is not a commercial entity; and
The plant is removed according to the provisions of Regulation .06G of this chapter.

For approvals not granted under §C of this regulation, a person may submit a written request to the Secretary for approval of any activity allowed under §B of this regulation with the following information:
Name;
Business, nursery, or plant dealer license number if applicable;
Phone;
Email address;
Prohibited invasive plant for which approval is being requested (full botanical name);
Specific location of the prohibited invasive plant;
Proposed activity;
Method of safeguarding dispersal of all propagules and all other living parts of the prohibited invasive plant;
Time frame of the proposed activity; and
Any other information required by the Secretary.
Upon notice and an opportunity to be heard, the Secretary may:
Withdraw or revoke any approval for any person who violates any condition of any approval by the Secretary; or
Revise any approval as a condition of any permit, based on new information obtained after an approval is granted.

The Secretary may issue administrative orders to enforce the provisions of this chapter and Agriculture Article, Title 9.5 (Invasive Plants Prevention and Control), Annotated Code of Maryland, as follows:
Order any person to cease propagating, importing, transferring, selling, purchasing, transporting, or introducing any living part of a prohibited invasive plant in the State;
Order the condemnation and seizure of any prohibited invasive plant owned or possessed by any person who violates Agriculture Article, §9.5-302(b), Annotated Code of Maryland;
Order the marking or tagging in a conspicuous manner of a prohibited invasive plant owned or controlled by any person subject to an order of the Secretary under this chapter;

Order any person, on notice from the Secretary, to dispose of any prohibited invasive plant that is held in violation of this chapter or in violation of Agriculture Article, Title 9.5, Annotated Code of Maryland, in a manner that renders all plant parts nonviable, or allow a person to return a prohibited invasive plant to the out-of-State supplier of the plant, as approved in advance by the Secretary;

Order a person to make any prohibited invasive plant available to the Secretary for destruction if the person has failed to dispose of the prohibited invasive plant as ordered by the Secretary and require that person to pay any destruction cost;
Order a person to take any action that the Secretary considers necessary to enforce the requirements of Agriculture Article, Title 9.5, Annotated Code of Maryland.
A person who violates any order issued by the Secretary is subject to a civil penalty not to exceed $500 for each violation.

section.heading: Prohibited Invasive Plants and Watchlist Plants.

para.text: The Prohibited invasive plants are those plants listed on the Consolidated List of Maryland Invasive Plant Species found on the Maryland Department of Agriculture’s website, Plant Protection and Weed Management page.
Phase-out periods for Prohibited Invasive Plants.

A person in possession of a prohibited invasive plant, except a person who is growing a woody plant in ground, shall comply with the prohibited invasive plant provisions of this chapter within 1 year of that plant’s effective date on the prohibited invasive plant list.
A person who is growing a prohibited invasive plant in ground shall comply with the provisions of this chapter within 2 years from that plant’s effective date on the prohibited invasive plant list.
A person may not acquire a new prohibited invasive plant after that plant’s effective date on the prohibited invasive plant list.

Sales Limited to Existing Stock. During the phase-out period, a person may only sell the existing stock of a prohibited invasive plant that person has in inventory as of the date the plant was placed on the prohibited invasive plant list.
Exemption Request.

The Secretary may consider an exemption request from a nursery, broker or plant dealer licensed under Agriculture Article, §5-309, Annotated Code of Maryland to extend the phase-out period for a specific plant species that has been placed on the prohibited plant list.
In considering an exemption request, the Secretary shall:
Receive and consider input from the Invasive Plant Advisory Committee including the species’ economic harm, ecological harm, environmental harm, and harm to human health; and
Consider the economic impact that the phase-out period has on the affected person.
The person seeking the exemption shall submit a written request to the Secretary providing the same information specified in Regulation .04D of this chapter.
If the Secretary grants a person’s exemption request to extend the phase-out period for a specific plant species, the extension may not be more than 1 year.
The Secretary shall maintain a listing of plants on the Watch List, which listing may be amended from time to time.
Procedures for Classification or Declassification of a prohibited invasive plant and associated cultivars.

A person who requests the classification or declassification of a plant as a prohibited invasive plant, shall submit a written request to the Secretary that includes the name of the requestor, contact information, scientific name of the plant, and a justification for the request.
Upon receipt of the request the Secretary, in consultation with the Invasive Plant Advisory Committee, shall make a determination, considering:
Whether the plant is or could potentially be sold or marketed in the State;

If the plant has already been assessed pursuant to Regulation .03 of this chapter, whether new, science-based information is available that could change the species' designation as a prohibited invasive plant; and

If the plant has not been assessed pursuant to Regulation .03 of this chapter, whether the justification for the request, including documented scientific evidence of economic, ecological, or environmental harm, or harm to human health, necessitates formal weed status assessment, assessment of invasiveness, or both.
The Secretary shall notify the requestor of the final decision regarding the request.
Distribution of the Prohibited Invasive Plant List and the Watch List.
The Secretary shall send the Prohibited Invasive Plant List and the Watch List with annual renewal letters and with each new application for a nursery, plant dealer, or plant broker license.
The Secretary shall post the Prohibited Invasive Plant List and the Watch List on the Department's website.
A person in the business of providing landscaping services who plants or supplies for planting a plant on the Watch List shall provide to the customer requesting the service the Watch List.
Disposal of Prohibited Invasive Plants. Any person who removes a prohibited invasive plant off-site shall ensure that:
The plant is completely contained (for example, covered or securely tarped in a solid conveyance, or bagged) to prevent the escape of plant parts into the environment; and
If the plant is being removed for disposal, it is removed to a Maryland Department of Environment approved landfill or compost facility for burial or composting.

para.text: In this regulation, “sociological information” means:
Social Security number;
Individual taxpayer identification number;
Federal employer identification number;
Personal street address;
Personal phone number;
Personal e-mail address;
Date of birth;
Information regarding marital status, dependents, or relatives;
Information regarding employment status, including employment application;
Medical or psychiatric history;
Medical assistance;
Educational history; and
Driver’s license number.

All public records maintained by the Comptroller, other than those which the Comptroller is authorized or required to hold confidential under the Public Information Act, the Tax-General Article, or other law, shall be open for inspection at any time during regular business hours. A person seeking the right to inspect a public record maintained by the Comptroller, other than by means of written request, who is advised by the custodian that the Comptroller is authorized or required to hold the record confidential under the Public Information Act, may pursue the request by making written application to the Comptroller of the Treasury, State Treasury Building, Annapolis, Maryland.
A person who makes a written request for a public record maintained by the Comptroller shall include in the request:
A statement that the request is made pursuant to the Public Information Act;
A description of the public record sought to be inspected.
As soon as practicable, but not later than 30 days after receipt of the written request for access to any public record, the Comptroller shall either:
Grant the request by written notice and produce the record for inspection;
Deny the request, in whole or in part; or
Temporarily deny the request pending a court determination of whether disclosure would do substantial injury to the public interest.

The grant of a request for public inspection includes the right to copy the public record or to have it copied by the Comptroller's Office. If the Comptroller grants a request to inspect a public record, in whole or in part, the notice mailed to the applicant shall include the date, time, and place of the inspection, and the name of the employee of the Comptroller’s office to be contacted by the applicant for this purpose.

If the Comptroller denies, in whole or in part, a written request for the inspection of a public record in his possession, the Comptroller shall provide the applicant, within 10 working days of the denial, with a written statement of the grounds for the denial and the remedies available to the applicant for review of his decision.
Any time limit set forth in this regulation:
May be extended with the consent of the applicant, for a period not to exceed 30 days; or
Shall, if the applicant seeks resolution under General Provisions Article, §4-1B-04, Annotated Code of Maryland, be extended pending the resolution of the dispute.
Charges for Copies, Print-Outs, Electronic Files and Photographs.

When the duplication is performed by the applicant or by an employee of the Comptroller's Office without supervision by a senior official, on conventional duplicating equipment located in an office of the Comptroller, the charge for copies or photographs of a public record provided pursuant to this regulation shall be 50 cents per page. A charge of $1 per page shall be made for copies which the Comptroller is required to make in order to delete privileged or confidential information from public records which an applicant will personally inspect and for copies which must be made under the supervision of a senior official.

If copies or photographs cannot be made on equipment located in the office where the public records are kept, the Comptroller shall cause the copies to be made at a location of the Comptroller’s choosing, and shall charge for this service, in addition to charges incurred for duplication, an amount sufficient to reimburse the State for the cost of the time of an employee of the Comptroller’s office in supervising this copying.

If the Comptroller is required to provide a print-out or electronic file pursuant to this regulation, the Comptroller shall determine a reasonable charge for the print-out or electronic file on a case-by-case basis, taking into account computer time, programming, and material costs.

Except as provided in §J of this regulation, the custodian may not disclose and shall deny a request for inspection or copying of any part of a public record that contains sociological information relating to an individual.
Subject to §B of this regulation, a custodian may disclose sociological information:
That is anonymized and aggregated;
To other public officials and employees in the performance of their public duties;
To the person in interest or the agent or representative of the person in interest;
With the consent of the person in interest;
Pursuant to a duly issued subpoena; or
Pursuant to a court order.

para.text: Basic Statewide Trout Fishing. Except as listed in §§B—I of this regulation, the following shall be in effect for trout fishing in all nontidal waters of the State:
Open season — year around;
Fishing hours — from 5:30 a.m. to 10 p.m.;
Creel and possession limits (all species of trout) in aggregate — daily: 2, possession: 4;
A trout is part of the daily creel and possession limit if it cannot freely swim away from a person;
Minimum size (all species of trout) — no minimum size restriction.
Put-and-Take Trout Fishing Areas.

Open Season. Except as provided in §I of this regulation, put-and-take trout fishing areas are closed to all fishing from 10 p.m. of the first date to 5:30 a.m. of the last date, during the period listed in the following schedule:
Closure 0 — No closure; and
Closure 1 — From the first Sunday after March 4 to the last Saturday in March.
Fishing Hours.
Except as provided in §B(2)(b) and (c) and §I of this regulation, the fishing hours are from 5:30 a.m. to 10 p.m.
There are no time restrictions for fishing in impoundments of 5 acres or more.
In areas designated as Closure 1 in §B(5) of this regulation, the fishing hours on the last Saturday in March are from 6:30 a.m. to 10 p.m.
Creel and Possession Limits.
Brook trout v Daily: 0, Possession: 0.
All other species of trout in aggregate — Daily: 5, Possession: 10.

Public and private ponds in which State-supported fishing rodeos are held may be designated as put-and-take trout fishing areas on the day of the rodeo and are subject to the provisions in §B(1)—(3) of this regulation.
Except as provided in §C(1) of this regulation the following areas are designated as put-and-take trout fishing areas and are subject to the provisions in §B(1)—(3) of this regulation:

para.text: Catch-and-Return Trout Fishing Areas.
Owens Creek.
Special provisions in effect on this area:
From June 1 through the last day of February, a person may not keep or have any trout in possession while fishing, or fish with any barbed hook; and
A person may not possess or use any natural or live bait, or any device enhanced with a scent and capable of catching fish.
The area subject to the provisions of §C(1)(a) of this regulation is Owens Creek mainstem from Buck Lantz Road downstream to Roddy Road.
North Branch Potomac River.
Special provisions in effect on this area:
Open season — no closed season;
Creel and possession limits, all trout species in aggregate: daily — 0, possession — 0; and
A person may not fish with any barbed hook.

The area subject to the provisions of §C(2)(a) of this regulation is the North Branch Potomac River from the Upper Potomac River Commission Wastewater Treatment Plant discharge at Westernport downstream to the Maryland Route 956 bridge at Pinto.
Areas Limited to Use of Artificial Lures Only.
Special provisions in effect on these areas:
A person may not have any trout in possession while fishing in these areas. All trout which are caught shall be released and returned to the water.
A person may fish only with artificial lures, including artificial flies.
In these areas, a person may not possess or use any natural or live bait, or any device enhanced with a scent and capable of catching fish.
The open season for artificial lure fishing is January 1 through December 31, inclusive.
A person may not fish with any barbed hook.
Areas subject to the provisions of this section are:

Patuxent River, Howard and Montgomery counties. The mainstem of the Patuxent River from the crossing of Maryland Route 97 upstream to the crossing of Maryland Route 27 and Cabin Branch from its confluence with the Patuxent River upstream to Hipsley Mill Road.
Morgan Run, Carroll County. From bridge on London Bridges Road upstream to bridge on Maryland Route 97.
Paint Branch and Tributaries, Montgomery County upstream of Fairland Road.
Gunpowder Falls, Baltimore County. Mainstem, from Prettyboy Reservoir Dam downstream to Bluemount Road.

North Branch Potomac River from an overhead cable and red bank post located approximately 345 yards below the Jennings Randolph Reservoir spillway downstream approximately 1 mile to a red post, located approximately 100 yards above the upstream concrete abutments at Barnum, West Virginia, and from a red post located below a pool known as Blue Hole approximately 1/3 mile upstream of Bench Mark 1110 on the Westernport U.S.G.S. Quadrangle, downstream approximately 4 miles to the confluence of Piney Swamp Run.
Youghiogheny River, Garrett County. Mainstem beginning at a red post approximately 100 yards upstream of the Deep Creek Lake tailrace and extending downstream 4 miles to the Sang Run Bridge.

Little Hunting Creek, Frederick County. Mainstem from a red post located approximately 1/4 mile downstream of Maryland Route 806, upstream to include all waters of Little Hunting Creek within the boundaries of Cunningham Falls State Park.
Areas Limited to Artificial Fly Fishing Only.
Special provisions in effect on these areas:
A person may not have any trout in possession while fishing in these areas. All trout which are caught shall be released and returned to the water.

A person may fish only with artificial flies and streamers constructed in a normal fashion using natural or synthetic materials, or both, which may include feathers, fur, hair, tinsel, thread, fiber, plastic, cork, wire, and rubber, on a single hook with the components wound on or about the hook. A person may not use molded replicas of insects, earthworms, fish eggs, fish, or any invertebrate or vertebrate, either singly or in combination with the other materials, or other lures commonly described as spinners, spoons, or plugs made of metal, plastic, wood, rubber, or a similar substance or a combination of these.

A person may fish only with conventional fly fishing tackle, including fly rods, fly reels, and fly line with a leader or monofilament line attached. Any method of angling when the fly is cast directly from the reel is prohibited. The use of centerpin, spinning, spincast, and casting reels is prohibited.
In these areas, a person may not possess or use any natural or live bait, or any device enhanced with a scent and capable of catching fish.
The open season is January 1 through December 31, inclusive.
A person may not fish with any barbed hook.
Areas subject to provisions of this section are:

Big Hunting Creek, Frederick County. All waters of Big Hunting Creek and its tributaries within Cunningham Falls State Park and Catoctin Mountain Park except Owens Creek, Little Hunting Creek, Cunningham Falls Lake, and Frank Bentz Pond;
Beaver Creek, Washington County. From the confluence with Black Rock Creek downstream to the downstream side of the U.S. Route 40 bridge ; and
Patuxent River, Montgomery and Howard Counties. From red bank posts located on both sides of the river approximately 400 yards below Brighton Dam downstream to Mink Hollow Road.
Trophy Trout Fishing Areas.

Savage River mainstem from the downstream side of the Route 135 bridge upstream for a distance of approximately 2.7 miles to the lower suspension bridge (Allegany Bridge) is a trophy trout fishing area. The following apply:
Open season — no closed season.
Creel limit all trout species in aggregate — daily: 2, possession: 4.
Minimum size: brook trout — 12 inches; brown trout — 18 inches; all other species of trout — no minimum size.
A person may not have in possession any trout smaller than the minimum size limit in effect for this area.
A person may fish only with artificial lures, including artificial flies. Treble hooks are prohibited. Each artificial lure is restricted to a single hook with a single hook point.
In these areas, a person may not possess or use any natural or live bait, or any device enhanced with a scent and capable of catching fish.
Savage River mainstem from the Savage River Reservoir Dam downstream to the lower suspension bridge (Allegany Bridge) is a trophy trout fishing area. The following apply:
Open season — no closed season
Creel limit all trout species in aggregate — daily: 2, possession: 4.
Minimum size: brook trout — 12 inches; brown trout — 18 inches; all other species of trout — no minimum size.
A person may fish only with artificial flies.

In these areas, a person may not possess or use any natural or live bait, or any device enhanced with a scent and capable of catching fish. Section C(4)(a)(ii)—(iv), of this regulation shall apply to this special trout management area.
A person may not have in possession any trout smaller than the minimum size limit in effect for this area.
Areas Limited to Fishing by Persons Younger than 16 Years Old, Persons 65 Years Old or Older, and Blind Persons.
Special provisions in effect on these areas:
Fishing in these areas is limited to persons under 16 years old, persons 65 years old and older, and blind persons;
Section B(1)—(3) of this regulation shall apply to these special trout management areas.
Areas subject to provisions of this section:
Laurel Run (Moscow), Allegany County.
Pangborn Pond, Washington County.
Rising Sun Pond from March 1 through May 15.
Boonsboro Pond, Washington County.
Areas Limited to Fishing by Persons under 16 Years Old and Blind Persons.
Special provisions in effect on these areas.
Fishing in these areas is limited to individuals under 16 years old and blind persons.
Section B(1)—(3) of this regulation shall apply to these special trout management areas.
Areas subject to provisions of this section:
Carroll Creek from a red post located approximately 300 yards upstream of Baughmans Lane downstream to the dam at College Avenue;
Little Tonoloway Creek within Weidmeyer Park in Hancock;
Glades Park Pond on Liberty Street in Oakland;
George's Creek within Town Park in Westernport;
Little Antietam Creek at Keedysville, from Coffman Farms Road downstream to Maryland Route 34; and
Grantsville Parkview Pond off Hershberger Lane.
Delayed Harvest Trout Fishing Areas and Requirements.
Group I Delayed Harvest Trout Fishing Areas and Restrictions.
Group I Fishing Areas.
Catoctin and Little Catoctin Creek (Frederick County) from U.S. Route 40 near its intersection with Maryland Route 17 within Doubs Meadow Park downstream to the lower park boundary near Myersville.
Catoctin Creek (Frederick County) from the southernmost boundary of Catoctin Creek Park upstream to 200 feet north of the Sumantown Road Bridge.
Middle Patuxent River (Howard County) from U.S. Route 29 downstream to Murray Hill Road.

Town Creek mainstem (Allegany County) within Green Ridge State Forest, from a red post located approximately 3/4 mile downstream of the upper ford on lower Town Creek Road, just south of the Wagner Road intersection, downstream to a red post located just upstream of the lower ford on Lower Town Creek Road (Mallory Place), and from a post located approximately 1/2 mile downstream of Maniford Road to a red post located approximately 1-3/4 miles downstream (Bull Ring Ranch).

South Branch Patapsco River from West Friendship Road (Howard County) and Main Street (Carroll County) upstream approximately 1.1 mile to the upper boundary of the Hugg Thomas Wildlife Management Area.
Season, Creel, and Possession Limits for Group I Fishing Areas.
From June 1 through September 30, inclusive, the daily creel limit is five trout and the possession limit is ten trout (all species of trout in aggregate); and

From October 1 through May 31, inclusive, a person may not have any trout in possession while fishing in these areas, and shall immediately release any trout caught to the water from which the trout was taken.
Bait Restrictions for Group I Fishing Areas.
From June 1 through September 30, inclusive, no special bait, lure, or tackle restrictions are in effect.
From October 1 through May 31, inclusive, in these areas, a person may not possess or use any natural or live bait, or any device enhanced with a scent and capable of catching fish.
From October 1 through May 31, inclusive, in these areas, a person may not fish with any barbed hook.
Group II Delayed Harvest Trout Fishing Areas and Restrictions.
Group II Fishing Areas.

Casselman River mainstem (Garrett County) from a boundary marked by two red posts on both stream banks located on the south side of the Interstate 68 eastbound bridge downstream to the Pennsylvania state line.
North Branch Potomac River mainstem (Garrett County) from the lowermost boundary of the Potomac State Forest near Lostland Run to the uppermost boundary of the Potomac State Forest at Wallman.

Youghiogheny River mainstem (Garrett County) below Friendsville from a site located 50 yards downstream of Maple Street (at the confluence of Minnow Run) downstream 1.8 miles to the powerline crossing upstream of the Youghiogheny Reservoir.
Season, Creel, and Possession Limits for Group II Fishing Areas.
From June 16 through September 30, inclusive, the daily creel limit is five trout and the possession limit is ten trout (all species of trout in aggregate).

From October 1 through June 15, inclusive, a person may not have any trout in possession while fishing in these areas, and shall immediately release any trout caught to the water from which the trout was taken.
Bait Restrictions for Group II Fishing Areas.
From June 16 through September 30, inclusive, no special bait, lure, or tackle restrictions are in effect.
From October 1 through June 15, inclusive, in these areas, a person may not possess or use any natural or live bait, or any device enhanced with a scent and capable of catching fish.
From October 1 through June 15, inclusive, in these areas, a person may not fish with any barbed hook.
Special Restrictions for Brook Trout.
Nontidal Waters East of Interstate 81. A person may not have brook trout in possession while fishing in nontidal waters of the State located east of Interstate 81.
Savage River.
Special provisions in effect on this area:
A person may use only artificial flies and lures;
A person may not possess or use any natural or live bait, or any device enhanced with a scent and capable of catching fish; and
A person may not have brook trout in possession while fishing in this area.

The area subject to the provisions of §H(2)(a) of this regulation is the Savage River mainstem and tributaries upstream of the Savage River Reservoir dam, excluding impoundments and Put-and-Take Trout Fishing Areas (Savage River Reservoir, Savage River from Savage River Reservoir upstream to Poplar Lick Run, and New Germany Lake).
Youth Trout Fishing Day.
Youth trout fishing day is the Saturday before the last Saturday in March in areas designated as Closure 1 in §B of this regulation.
Fishing Hours. The fishing hours on youth trout fishing day are from 6:30 a.m. to 10 p.m.
Fishing in the areas during the date and times described in this section is limited to individuals younger than 16 years old.
Creel and Possession Limits.
Brook trout — Daily: 0, Possession: 0.
All other species of trout in aggregate — Daily: 2, Possession: 2.

Special Restrictions for Beaver Creek. A person may not have any brown trout in possession while fishing in Beaver Creek, from the confluence with Antietam Creek upstream to the Albert Powell State Trout Hatchery.
Largemouth Bass and Smallmouth Bass Slot Length Limit Fishing Areas.
The following special regulations are in effect in these areas during the open season for largemouth and smallmouth bass:
A person may possess five bass (largemouth and smallmouth bass in aggregate) per day while fishing in these areas;
A person may not possess any largemouth bass or smallmouth bass from 11 inches up to but not including 15 inches total length while fishing in these areas;
A person may possess one largemouth bass or smallmouth bass per day, 15 inches and over, while fishing in these areas.
The areas subject to this provision are:
St. Mary's Lake, Maryland Route 5, St. Mary's County;
Little Seneca Lake, Montgomery County;
Johnson Pond, Wicomico County; and
Leonard Mill Pond, Wicomico County.
Impoundments Limited to Catch-and-Return Fishing.
This section applies to the following areas:
Lake Hashawha in Carroll County;
Upper John Owings Pond in Carroll County; and
Waterworks Park in Anne Arundel County.
While fishing in the areas set forth in §B(1) of this regulation, a person:
Shall immediately return live any fish caught to the water where taken; and
May not keep or possess any fish while fishing in these areas.
Catch-and-Return Bass Areas.
Special provisions in effect for catch-and-return bass areas are that a person:
Who catches a largemouth or smallmouth bass shall immediately release that bass in the water where it was caught; and
May not possess largemouth or smallmouth bass while within the designated catch-and-return areas.
The areas subject to the provisions of this section are the:
Potomac River from Dam No. 2 (Seneca Breaks) upstream to the mouth of the Monocacy River;
Monocacy River from the Potomac River upstream to Buckeystown Dam; and
Patapsco River from Interstate 70 downstream to Maryland Route 144 (Frederick Road).

para.text: Chicamuxen Creek is a tributary of the Potomac River located in Charles County, encompassing the area beginning at a point, at or near Lat. 38° 32.557'N., Long. 77° 13.765' W., then running 347° (True) to a point, at or near Lat. 38° 32.620'N., Long. 77° 13.783' W., and running to the head of the creek. This area has a minimum wake zone from March 1 through June 15.

Pomonkey Creek is a tributary of the Potomac River located in Charles County, encompassing the area beginning at a point, at or near Lat. 38° 38.050' N., Long. 77º 6.3650' W., then running 299° (True) to a point, at or near Lat. 38° 38.062' N., Long. 77° 6.3920' W., and running to the head of the creek. This area has a minimum wake zone from March 1 through June 15.
Westmoreland State Park.

Area. All of the waters of the Potomac River enclosed by a line beginning at a point at or near Lat. 38°10.447' N., Long. 76°52.746' W., then running 34° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°10.495' N., Long. 76°52.705' W., then running 113° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°10.340' N., Long. 76°52.248' W., then running 204° True to a point at or near Lat. 38°10.295' N., Long. 76°52.273' W., then running along the shore to the point of beginning.
The area described in §C(1) of this regulation is a minimum wake zone during the boating season.

para.text: The South River north shore areas, with their corresponding speed limits, are set forth in §§B—L of this regulation.
Aberdeen Creek.

Lower Aberdeen Creek encompasses the area upstream of a line beginning at a point at or near Lat. 38° 56.510' N., Long. 76° 31.400' W., then running 91° (True) to a point, at or near Lat. 38° 56.507' N., Long. 76° 31.232' W., and downstream of a line beginning at a point at or near Lat. 38° 56.787' N., Long. 76° 31.263' W., then running 82° (True) to a point, at or near Lat. 38° 56.800' N., Long. 76° 31.140' W. This area has a 6-knot speed limit Saturdays, Sundays, and State holidays, during the boating season.

Upper Aberdeen Creek encompasses the area upstream of a line beginning at a point at or near Lat. 38° 56.787' N., Long. 76° 31.263' W., then running 82° (True) to a point, at or near Lat. 38° 56.800' N., Long. 76° 31.140' W., and running to the head of the creek. This area has a 6-knot speed limit, during the boating season.

Boyd Point Cove encompasses the area upstream of a line beginning at a point at or near Lat. 38° 57.380' N., Long. 76° 33.960' W., then running 79° (True) to a point, at or near Lat. 38° 57.383' N., Long. 76° 33.938' W., and running to the head of the cove. This area has a 6-knot speed limit all year.
Broad Creek.

Lower Broad Creek encompasses the area upstream of a line beginning at Porter Point, at or near Lat. 38° 57.547' N., Long. 76° 34.625' W., then running 110° (True) to Addison Point, at or near Lat. 38° 57.495' N., Long. 76° 34.447' W., and downstream of a line beginning at a point at or near Lat. 38° 58.113' N., Long. 76° 34.538' W., then running 281° (True) to a point, at or near Lat. 38° 58.127' N., Long. 76° 34.625' W. This area has a:
20-knot speed limit, sunset to sunrise, during the boating season;
35-knot speed limit, sunrise to sunset, during the boating season.

Upper Broad Creek encompasses the area upstream of a line beginning at a point at or near Lat. 38° 58.113' N., Long. 76° 34.538' W., then running 281° (True) to a point, at or near Lat. 38° 58.127' N., Long. 76° 34.625' W., and running to the head of the creek. This area has a:
6-knot speed limit Saturdays, Sundays, and State holidays, during the boating season;
20-knot speed limit, weekdays, sunset to sunrise, during the boating season;
35-knot speed limit, weekdays, sunrise to sunset, during the boating season.

Cherrytree Cove encompasses the area upstream of a line beginning at a point at or near Lat. 38° 55.412' N., Long. 76° 28.992' W., then running 152° (True) to a point, at or near Lat. 38° 55.217' N., Long. 76° 28.857' W., and running to the head of the cove. This area has a minimum wake zone all year.

Church Creek encompasses the area upstream of a line beginning at a point at or near Lat. 38° 57.115' N., Long. 76° 32.412' W., then running 84° (True) to a point, at or near Lat. 38° 57.128' N., Long. 76° 32.258' W., and running to the head of the creek. This area has a 6-knot speed limit, during the boating season.

Crab Creek encompasses the area upstream of a line beginning at a point at or near Lat. 38° 57.128' N., Long. 76° 32.078' W., then running 55° (True) to a point, at or near Lat. 38° 57.197' N., Long. 76° 31.955' W., and running to the head of the creek. This area has a 6-knot speed limit, during the boating season.
Duvall Creek.

Area. All of the waters north of a line beginning at a point at or near Lat. 38° 55.652' N., Long. 76° 29.425' W., then running 116° True to a point at or near Lat. 38° 55.542' N., Long. 76° 29.140' W.
The speed limit for the area described in §H(1) of this regulation is 6 knots during the boating season.

Gingerville Creek encompasses the area upstream of a line beginning at a point at or near Lat. 38° 57.332' N., Long. 76° 33.372' W., then running 61° (True) to a point, at or near Lat. 38° 57.377' N., Long. 76° 33.268' W., and running to the head of the creek. This area has a 6-knot speed limit all year.

Harness Creek encompasses the area upstream of a line beginning at a point at or near Lat. 38° 55.942' N., Long. 76° 30.900' W., then running 92° (True) to a point, at or near Lat. 38° 55.933' N., Long. 76° 30.640' W., and running to the head of the creek. This area has a 6-knot speed limit all year.

Hillsmere Lake encompasses the area upstream of a line beginning at a point at or near Lat. 38° 55.685' N., Long. 76° 30.073' W., then running 322° (True) to a point, at or near Lat. 38° 55.692' N., Long. 76° 30.080' W., and running to the head of the lake. This area has a 6-knot speed limit all year.

Little Aberdeen Creek encompasses the area upstream of a line beginning at a point at or near Lat. 38° 56.773' N., Long. 76° 31.740' W., then running 111° (True) to a point, at or near Lat. 38° 56.747' N., Long. 76° 31.652' W., and running to the head of the creek. This area has a 6-knot speed limit, during the boating season.

para.text: Except as provided in §A-1 of this regulation, in claiming races a horse is subject to claim for its entered price by:
A licensed owner;
An individual authorized to claim in behalf of a registered stable or other multiple ownership entity; or
A registered authorized agent in behalf of a person listed in §A(1) or (2) of this regulation.
In claiming races a horse is not subject to claim if:
The horse has not started for a minimum of 120 days;
The last start of the horse was a claiming race;
The horse is entered for a claiming price not less than the claiming price of its last start;
For the first race following the period specified in §A-1(1) of this regulation, the horse is declared ineligible to be claimed at the time of entry; and
The program clearly designates that the horse is ineligible to be claimed.
Eligibility to Claim.

Except as provided in §B(2) and (3) of this regulation, to be eligible to claim, a licensed owner, registered stable, or other multiple ownership entity shall designate, as the person who will assume control and responsibility of a claimed horse, a licensed trainer who has been assigned stabling on grounds under the jurisdiction of the Commission.

A licensed owner, registered stable, or other multiple ownership entity that does not have a licensed trainer with assigned stabling on grounds under the jurisdiction of the Commission is eligible to claim only to replace a horse lost to a claim at a track under the jurisdiction of the Commission.
A trainer who is also licensed as an owner, and whose trainer's license is suspended, is not eligible to claim a horse as an owner during the term of the suspension.
A person shall not be eligible to claim more than one horse in a race, either directly or through another.
A valid claim shall:
Be in writing on a form provided by the association;
Be in the name of a person qualified to claim a horse;
Be signed by the person, or the agent of the person, in whose name the claim is made;
Contain the name of the horse to be claimed in a manner sufficient to avoid confusion with the name of another horse in the race;
Name the trainer who will assume control and responsibility of the horse to be claimed;
Be for the amount printed in the program as the claiming price of the horse;
Be enclosed in a sealed envelope, provided by the association, which shall contain no identifying marks on its outside other than the number of the race in which the claimed horse is to participate;
Be deposited in a lock box of the claims clerk at least 10 minutes before the post time for the race in which the claimed horse is to participate; and

Be supported by funds on deposit at the association in the name of the claimant in an amount sufficient to cover the cost of the claim, any taxes to which the claim may be subject, and 1.5 percent of the claiming price, which shall be paid to the horse retirement program approved by the organization representing the majority of horsemen.
After the deadline for entering a claim has passed, the stewards or their designee shall:
Open the claim envelopes for the race;
If the same trainer is named on more than one claim form, conduct a drawing of those forms, which results in the trainer being named on only one claim form;
After ascertaining compliance with §§D and E of this regulation, if there is more than one valid claim for a horse, conduct a drawing to determine the successful claimant; and
Notify the Racing Secretary of the identity of the successful claimant and the horse claimed.

The stewards may require a person who submits a claim for a horse in a claiming race to make an affidavit declaring that the person is claiming the horse for the person's own account or for the account of another as the registered authorized agent for that person.
If the stewards determine that a horse was improperly entered in a claiming race, they may:
Void a claim of the horse;
Order the claiming monies, including all taxes, refunded to the claimant through the Clerk of the Course, the horsemen's bookkeeper, or otherwise; and
Order the return of the horse to the original owner.
Except as provided in §H-1 or H-2 of this regulation, unless there is a violation of this regulation by the claimant, or the stewards determine that a horse was improperly entered:
The claim is irrevocable and the claimed horse becomes the property of the successful claimant from the time the horse is a starter; and
A purse earned in the race from which a horse is claimed is the property of the owner from whom the horse is claimed.
A claim shall be voided if a horse is a starter and the horse:
Dies on the racetrack; or
Suffers an injury which requires the euthanasia of the horse, as determined by a State veterinarian, while the horse is on the racetrack.
A claim is voidable at the sole discretion of the new owner, for a period of 1 hour after the race is made official, for any horse that:
Is vanned off the track after the race at the discretion of the State Veterinarian; or
Is sent to the detention barn and observed to be lame by the State Veterinarian.
After the race has been run, the successful claimant shall present verification of the claim by the Racing Secretary to the person accompanying the claimed horse.
A properly claimed horse shall be delivered to the successful claimant in the:
Paddock, immediately after the running of the race, if the horse is not subject to post-race testing; or
Detention area, after the horse has undergone post-race testing, if the horse is subject to that testing.
If a trainer refuses to deliver a horse that has been claimed to the successful claimant when verification of the claim is presented in accordance with §I of this regulation, the:
Trainer is subject to sanctions; and
Claimed horse shall be disqualified from participating in further racing until delivery is made.
In claiming races, the following acts, or an attempt to commit the following acts, are prohibited:
An agreement to claim, or not to claim, a horse belonging to another owner;
Preventing an owner from:
Claiming a horse, or
Legitimately running a horse in a race;
The claiming of a horse by:
The owner of the horse,
Another person for the account of the owner of the horse, or
One owner from another if the trainer of the horse to be claimed trains a horse owned by the entity making the claim; and
The entry of a horse if there is:

A lien or other encumbrance affecting the transfer of title to the horse unless there is written permission from the holder of the lien or other encumbrance, attached to the horse's foal certificate, allowing the horse to be entered in a claiming race,
An ownership dispute, or
One owner from another if the trainer of the horse to be claimed trains a horse owned by the entity making the claim; and
If a horse is claimed:
The horse shall not be eligible to start in a claiming race for less than 25 percent more than the claiming price for a period of 20 days from the date of the claim;
For the period of the 21st through the 30th day after the horse is claimed, the horse may only start in a claiming race at a price equal to or greater than the amount for which it was claimed; and
For the period after the 30th day after the horse is claimed, the horse may start in a claiming race at any claiming price.
The horse may not be sold or transferred to anyone, wholly or in part, for a period of 30 days from the day of the claim, except:
In a claiming race, or
When the horse is entered and starts for a claiming price which would cause the horse to become ineligible to be entered at Laurel or Pimlico;
Unless reclaimed, the horse may not remain in the same stable or under the control or management of its former owner or trainer for a period of 30 days from the day of the claim;
It may not race outside of Maryland for a period of 60 days from the day of the claim except:
To participate in a stakes race;
To participate in a claiming race for a price which would cause the horse to become ineligible to be entered at Laurel or Pimlico; or
During the scheduled absence of a live thoroughbred race meet in Maryland for at least 15 days.
For the purposes of §M of this regulation, the day of the claim does not count in computing the time restrictions.
The stewards shall report action taken by them, in reference to a violation of this regulation, to the Commission which may, in its discretion, take any further action it considers appropriate.

A horse which was claimed in another state and entered to race in this State remains subject to the conditions of the claiming regulation in the state where the claim was made until those conditions expire.
Notwithstanding information printed in the program or other racing publications, the claimant is solely responsible for determining the horse's:
Age;
Breeding;
Physical condition;
Racing record; and
Sex.
National Steeplechase and Hunt Association.

At race meetings conducted by the Cecil County Breeders' Fair, Inc., claiming races shall be run under the conditions of the Rules of the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association, Part XXIII, Rule 203, N.B., as amended 1972.

For the purpose of defining a "meeting" as it applies to the eligibility of an owner to make a claim, all meetings sanctioned by the Hunts Committee of the N. S. & H. A. conducted between January 1st and June 30th of any one calendar year shall be deemed to be "one meeting", and all meetings conducted between July 1st and December 31st of any one calendar year shall be deemed to be "one meeting".

Each person desiring to make a claim, unless he has the amount to his credit with the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association, shall first deposit at the office of the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association the whole amount of the claim in cash, for which a receipt will be given; but any owner who is eligible to make a claim may do so without having the necessary funds on deposit as outlined above, provided that he delivers to an authorized representative of the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association at the race course not later than 30 minutes before post time of the 1st race of the meeting at which the claim is to be made, funds which are sufficient to cover the whole amount of the claim. These funds shall be in the form of a cashier's, treasurer's, or certified check only.

A horse which has been claimed may not race, other than at race meetings sanctioned by the Hunts Committee of the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association, until after the close of the meeting at which it was claimed, or for a period of 30 days, whichever comes first.

Annotation: COMAR 09.10.01.03O is cited in Attorney General Opinion No. 81-018 (July 16, 1981) which found that the Thoroughbred Racing Board of the Maryland Racing Commission has the authority to require that all purses won by horsemen be maintained by a racing association in a special interest-bearing account until paid to the horsemen and that the Board may provide for the use and disposition of the interest earned on these accounts, to some extent.
Annotation: COMAR 09.10.01.78 cited in Attorney General Opinion No. 87-033 (August 4, 1987)

para.text: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.

“Affiliated individual” means an individual who is 18 years old or older who has been designated in writing by a participating facility to serve either as a health supervisor or as a certificate holder.
“Agent” means an individual who:
Is 18 years old or older;
Has successfully completed, at the expense of the participating facility, an emergency epinephrine educational training program approved by the Department; and
Is designated in writing by a certificate holder to administer emergency use epinephrine in an emergency situation.
“Anaphylaxis” means a sudden, severe, and potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that occurs when an individual is exposed to an allergen.
“Applicant” means an individual applying for a Certificate for Emergency Epinephrine.

“Certificate for emergency epinephrine” means a certificate issued by the Maryland Department of Health to an individual employed or designated by a participating facility to obtain, store, and administer emergency use epinephrine.
“Certificate holder” means an individual who is authorized by the Maryland Department of Health to obtain, store, and administer emergency use epinephrine to be used in an emergency situation.
“Department” means the Maryland Department of Health.

“Eligible institution” means an institution of higher education that has a food service facility or a recreation and wellness facility on the premises and that otherwise meets the requirements of this chapter.

“Emergency use epinephrine” means a portable, disposable drug delivery device or product approved by the federal Food and Drug Administration that contains a premeasured single dose of epinephrine that is used to treat anaphylaxis in an emergency situation.
“Food service facility” has the meaning stated in COMAR 10.15.03.
“Health supervisor” means an individual who:
Provides health services for a participating facility; and
Is licensed by the State as a:
Physician;
Certified nurse practitioner; or
Registered nurse.

“Participating facility” means a recreation or wellness facility at an eligible institution or a food service facility, including a food service facility at an eligible institution, in the State that voluntarily participates in the Program.
“Successfully completed” means to pass a written examination with a grade of 75 percent or higher.
An individual may apply, on a form prescribed by the Department, for a certificate for emergency epinephrine, which shall be valid for up to 1 year if the applicant:
Is employed by a participating facility;
Is 18 years old or older; and
Has successfully completed, at the expense of the participating facility, an emergency epinephrine educational training program approved by the Department.
The applicant shall submit to the Department with the form required in §A of this regulation a written policy that includes:
Designation of agents and affiliated individuals;
The name of the approved emergency epinephrine educational training program; and
Procedures to:
Store emergency use epinephrine;
Maintain the emergency use epinephrine in a secure manner;
Report use of emergency use epinephrine according to §L of this regulation;
Train an emergency epinephrine certificate holder and agent annually; and
Maintain documentation of an emergency epinephrine certificate holder and agent training for 3 years.
A provider of an emergency epinephrine educational training program shall meet the requirements of COMAR 10.16.07.15C and D.
An individual teaching an emergency epinephrine educational training program shall be licensed as a physician, a registered nurse, or a certified nurse practitioner.
The Department shall:
Issue a certificate for emergency epinephrine to an applicant who meets the requirements in §§A and B of this regulation;
Deny the issuance of a certificate for emergency epinephrine to an applicant who does not meet the requirements in §§A and B of this regulation;
Revoke or suspend the certificate for emergency epinephrine of an individual who does not meet the requirements in §§A and B of this regulation;
Approve an emergency epinephrine educational training program if the training program meets the requirements of §C of this regulation;
Disapprove an emergency epinephrine educational training program if the training program does not meet the requirement of §C of this regulation; and

On or before January 31 of each year, publish a report summarizing the information obtained from the reported uses of emergency use epinephrine at participating facilities according to §L of this regulation.
A physician licensed to practice medicine in the State may prescribe emergency use epinephrine in the name of a certificate holder.
A pharmacist licensed to practice pharmacy in the State, or a physician, may dispense emergency use epinephrine under a prescription issued to a certificate holder.
A certificate holder may:
On presentment of a certificate for emergency epinephrine, receive from any physician licensed to practice medicine in the State a prescription for emergency use epinephrine; and
Possess and store prescribed emergency use epinephrine.
A participating facility:
Shall ensure that there is a written plan for the emergency epinephrine program that:
Is approved annually, in writing, by a health supervisor;
Is on file at the participating facility and is available for inspection; and
Includes at a minimum:
The name, title, and license number of the health supervisor;
Information on the emergency epinephrine educational training program used;
Procedures for disseminating information to staff on the emergency epinephrine program;
Procedures for the proper storage and handling of medication;
Procedures for the use of emergency services and 911 services; and
Procedures for documenting incidents involving the administration of emergency use epinephrine by a certificate holder in accordance with §L of this regulation;
Shall ensure that a certificate holder who is employed by, or a designated affiliated individual of, the participating facility complies with all provisions of this chapter;
Shall provide the Department with access to records and documents required under this chapter;
Shall designate in writing the certificate holders who will be responsible for the storage, maintenance, and control of the supply of emergency use epinephrine;
May not obtain or store emergency use epinephrine unless the participating facility has at least two certificate holders; and
Shall maintain a copy of the certificate issued to a certificate holder under §E of this regulation for at least 3 years.
Certificate Holders.
Subject to §I(4) of this regulation, a certificate holder may obtain:
A prescription for a supply of emergency use epinephrine from a licensed physician as provided in §F of this regulation; and
A supply of emergency use epinephrine from a licensed pharmacist or a licensed physician as provided in §G of this regulation.
A certificate holder shall store a supply of emergency use epinephrine obtained under §J(1) of this regulation:
In accordance with the manufacturer’s instructions; and
In a location that is readily accessible to certificate holders and agents in an emergency situation.

In an emergency situation when physician or emergency medical services are not immediately available, a certificate holder or agent may administer emergency use epinephrine to an individual who is experiencing or believed in good faith by the certificate holder or agent to be experiencing anaphylaxis.

A participating facility shall ensure that an incident that occurred on the premises of the facility that involved the administration of emergency use epinephrine by a certificate holder or agent is reported:
Immediately to the health supervisor and, in the case of a minor, to the minor’s parent or guardian; and
To the Department within 5 business days of the incident on a form prescribed by the Department.

annotations.annotation: Health-General Article, §§2-104 and 13-7A-03, Annotated Code of Maryland
Effective date: May 20, 2019 (46:10 Md. R. 487)
Regulation .01 amended effective July 12, 2021 (48:14 Md. R. 538)
Regulation .02B amended effective July 12, 2021 (48:14 Md. R. 538); February 16, 2026 (53:3 Md. R. 122)
Regulation .03 amended effective July 12, 2021 (48:14 Md. R. 538); February 16, 2026 (53:3 Md. R. 122)

para.text: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.

“Acute illness” means an abnormal condition of the body with rapid onset associated with recognizable symptoms and signs, such as chicken pox, gastroenteritis, influenza, or streptococcal sore throat, which has a short course of duration, as opposed to a chronic illness of long duration lasting 30 calendar days or more.
Administer Medication.
“Administer medication” means the act of providing, preparing, or applying a medication.
“Administer medication” does not include:
Reminding a camper to take a medication; or
Providing physical assistance with opening and removing a medication from the container or locked storage.
“Adult” has the meaning stated in COMAR 10.16.06.02.
“Agent” means an individual who:
Is at least 18 years old;
Has successfully completed, at the expense of an applicant, an emergency epinephrine educational training program approved by the Department; and
Is appointed by a certificate for emergency epinephrine holder to administer emergency use epinephrine in an emergency situation.
“Anaphylaxis” means a sudden, severe, and potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that occurs when an individual is exposed to an allergen.
“Applicant” means an individual applying for a Certificate for Emergency Epinephrine.
“Camp” means a youth camp as defined in COMAR 10.16.06.02.
“Camper” has the meaning stated in COMAR 10.16.06.02.

“Certificate” means a document showing the authority to operate a youth camp, issued by the Maryland Department of Health pursuant to COMAR 10.16.06 and Health-General Article, §14-403, Annotated Code of Maryland, which displays the name of the person granted the authority.

“Certificate for emergency epinephrine” means a certificate or an endorsement on the operating certificate of a youth camp issued by the Maryland Department of Health to an individual who operates a youth camp under COMAR 10.16.06 to obtain, store, and administer emergency use epinephrine.

“Certificate for emergency epinephrine holder” means an individual who is authorized by the Maryland Department of Health to obtain, store, and administer emergency use epinephrine to be used in an emergency situation.
“Day” has the meaning stated in COMAR 10.16.06.02.
“Department” has the meaning stated in COMAR 10.16.06.02.
“Director” has the meaning stated in COMAR 10.16.06.02.
“Emergency medication” means a medication, identified by a camper’s plan of action for use in case of a medical emergency, for a camper with an identified medical problem.

“Emergency use epinephrine” means a portable, disposable drug delivery device or product approved by the federal Food and Drug Administration that contains a premeasured single dose of epinephrine that is used to treat anaphylaxis in an emergency situation.
“Health supervisor” means an individual who:
Provides health services for a camp; and
Is licensed by the State as a:
Physician;
Certified nurse practitioner; or
Registered nurse.
Identified Medical Problem.
“Identified medical problem” means a chronic physical condition diagnosed by a licensed health care professional that:
Requires specific medical treatment and supervision; and
If untreated, can adversely affect the general health of the camper.
“Identified medical problem” includes, but is not limited to:
Asthma;
Cancer;
Diabetes; and
Epilepsy.

“Identified medical problem” does not include a chronic physical condition, which does not typically cause other medical problems or have an adverse effect on the general health of the camper, such as:
Blindness;
Deafness; or
A developmental disability.
“Medication” means any nonprescription or prescription medication present at camp.
“Operate” means to supervise, control, conduct, or manage a youth camp as:
An owner;
An agent of the owner;
A lessee of the owner;
A director; or
An independent contractor.
“Operator” has the meaning stated in COMAR 10.16.06.02.
“Person” has the meaning stated in COMAR 10.16.06.02.
“Secretary” has the meaning stated in COMAR 10.16.06.02.
“Self-administer medication” means the act of an individual’s ingesting, injecting, or applying the individual’s own medication when the individual:
Identifies the individual’s own medication; and
Follows the directions for use, including the correct route, dose, and frequency.
“Successfully completed” means to pass a written examination with a grade of 75 percent or higher.

section.heading: Required Health Reports.
section.text: For all campers, staff members, and volunteers, an operator shall ensure that:

para.text: An injury or illness that results in death or that requires resuscitation or admission to a hospital is reported:
Immediately to the health supervisor and, in the case of a minor, to the minor’s parent or guardian;
Verbally to the Department within 24 hours; and
To the Department within 1 week of the incident, on a form that meets the requirements of Regulation .07 of this chapter;
An injury that is treated at an off-site medical facility and that results in a positive diagnosis through clinical examination, laboratory test, or X-ray is reported:
Immediately to the health supervisor and, in the case of a minor, to the minor’s parent or guardian; and
To the Department within 4 weeks of the end of camp on a form that meets the requirements of Regulation .07 of this chapter;

When a camp health supervisor is on duty at the camp, an accident with no apparent injury, such as a fall from a horse, a fall from equipment, or impact from sports equipment, is reported immediately to the health supervisor;

When a camp health supervisor is only available for consultation and not on duty at the camp, the minor’s parent or guardian is notified as soon as possible and before the end of the camp day, verbally or in writing, of:
An illness or injury that is not included in §A or B of this regulation; or
An accident with no apparent injury, such as:
A fall from a horse;
A fall from equipment; or
Impact from sports equipment;
An outbreak of a disease or a condition that is required to be reported pursuant to COMAR 10.06.01 is reported:
Immediately to the health supervisor and in the case of a minor, to the minor’s parent or guardian;
Verbally to the Department within 24 hours; and
To the Department within 1 week of the incident on a form that meets the requirements of Regulation .07 of this chapter;
A medication error or incident that required the administration of emergency use epinephrine is reported:
Immediately to the health supervisor and, in the case of a minor, to the minor’s parent or guardian; and
To the Department within 4 weeks of the end of camp on a form that meets the requirements of Regulation .07 of this chapter; and
A camp health supervisor and camp director shall:
Annually review all health log records and identify opportunities to reduce incidents, accidents, injuries, and medication errors; and
Make available to the Department for review written documentation of the findings of the review of health log records.
An individual may apply, on a form prescribed by the Department, for a certificate for emergency epinephrine, which shall be valid for up to 1 year if the applicant:
Is an operator of a youth camp;
Is at least 18 years old; and
Has successfully completed, at the applicant’s expense, an emergency epinephrine educational training program approved by the Department.
The applicant shall submit to the Department with the form required in §A of this regulation a written policy that includes:
Designation of agents;
The name of the approved emergency epinephrine educational training program; and
Procedures to:
Store emergency use epinephrine;
Notify a parent or guardian that emergency use epinephrine is available at camp;
Maintain the emergency use epinephrine in a secure manner;
Report use of emergency use epinephrine according to Regulation .06 of this chapter;
Train an emergency epinephrine certificate holder and agent annually; and
Maintain documentation of an emergency epinephrine certificate holder and agent training for 3 years.
A provider of an emergency epinephrine educational training program may apply to the Department to have the training program recognized as approved for 5 years by submitting:
An application form prescribed by the Department;
A copy of all training program materials, including but not limited to handouts, presentations, and exams; and
The following credentials of the instructor:
Name;
License type as required in §E of this regulation; and
License number.
An emergency epinephrine educational training program shall include:
The signs and symptoms of anaphylaxis;
Use of an emergency use epinephrine pen;
Follow-up procedures with a parent or guardian after an emergency use epinephrine is administered;
A skills demonstration; and
A written examination.
An individual teaching an emergency epinephrine educational training program shall be licensed as a physician, a registered nurse, or a certified nurse practitioner.
The Department shall:
Issue a certificate for emergency epinephrine to an applicant who meets the requirements in §§A and B of this regulation;
Deny, revoke or suspend a certificate for emergency epinephrine from an applicant who does not meet the requirements in §§A and B of this regulation;
Approve an emergency epinephrine educational training program if the training program meets the requirements of §C of this regulation;
Disapprove an emergency epinephrine educational training program if the training program does not meet the requirement of §C of this regulation; and

On or before January 31 of each year, publish a report summarizing the information obtained from the Reportable Incident Report Forms submitted to the Department related to the use of emergency use epinephrine at youth camps.
A physician licensed to practice medicine in the State may prescribe emergency use epinephrine in the name of a certificate for emergency epinephrine holder.
A pharmacist licensed to practice pharmacy in the State or a physician may dispense emergency use epinephrine under a prescription issued to a certificate for emergency epinephrine holder.
A certificate for emergency epinephrine holder may:
On presentment of a certificate for emergency epinephrine, receive from any physician licensed to practice medicine in the State a prescription for auto-injectable epinephrine; and
Possess and store prescribed auto-injectable epinephrine.

In an emergency situation when physician or emergency medical services are not immediately available, a certificate for emergency epinephrine holder or agent may administer emergency use epinephrine to an individual who is experiencing or believed in good faith by the certificate for emergency epinephrine holder or agent to be experiencing anaphylaxis.

container.heading: Automatic External Defibrillators at Grocery Stores and Restaurants

para.text: This chapter establishes guidelines for periodic inspections and annual maintenance of AEDs at grocery stores and restaurants.
This chapter does not apply to:
A grocery store that has an annual gross income of $10,000,000 or less in a calendar year; or
A restaurant with:
An annual gross income of $1,000,000 or less in a calendar year, exclusive of sales for off-premises consumption; or
A seating capacity of less than 100 individuals based on a fire marshal’s determination.
In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
“AED” means automated external defibrillator as defined in COMAR 30.06.01.01.
“Department” means the Maryland Department of Health.
“Grocery store” means a store that has:
All major food departments, including produce, meat, seafood, dairy, and canned and packaged goods; or
At least one of the major food departments and at least 12,000 square feet of floor space.
“MIEMSS” means the Maryland Institute for Emergency Medical Services Systems.
“Restaurant” means a food service facility licensed under COMAR 10.15.03 that prepares food for on-site consumption.

section.heading: AED Requirements.
section.text: Beginning January 1, 2025, each owner and operator of a grocery store or restaurant subject to this chapter shall:

para.text: Place an AED in a prominent area, accessible to employees and customers; and
Maintain the functionality of the AED.

section.heading: Registration.
section.text: Each grocery store or restaurant subject to this chapter shall register with MIEMSS using a form prescribed by MIEMSS in order to:

para.text: Make its location publicly available to emergency dispatchers; and
Receive maintenance and recall notices from MIEMSS.

section.heading: Quality Assurance, Maintenance, and Reporting.
section.text: An owner or operator of a grocery store or restaurant subject to this chapter shall:

para.text: Maintain:
Each AED and all related equipment and supplies in accordance with the standards established by the device manufacturer and the U.S. Food and Drug Administration; and
Supplemental equipment with the AED at all times, including:
Two sets of defibrillator chest pads that are compatible with the AED;
Disposable gloves; and
The Maryland Facility AED Report Forms for Cardiac Arrest; and
Submit to MIEMSS:
A report for each incident of suspected cardiac arrest at the restaurant or grocery store on the Maryland Facility AED Report Form for Cardiac Arrests, including:
Contact information for any necessary follow-up; and
If created by the AED, any available event code, summary code, recording, or tape; and
If the AED fails when operated, in addition to submitting the required report to the federal Food and Drug Administration, a copy of the report provided to the federal Food and Drug Administration.
The Department shall:
Monitor a grocery store or restaurant subject to this chapter for compliance with this chapter; and
Inspect the grocery store or restaurant as necessary for the enforcement of this chapter.
Right to Inspect.

The Department may enter, at reasonable times, the property of a grocery store or restaurant for the purposes of inspecting, monitoring, and verifying information relative to the enforcement of this chapter.
A person may not deny or interfere with the Department’s entry into a grocery store or restaurant under this chapter.
An operator shall permit a representative of the Department to examine and copy records of the grocery store or restaurant to verify information relative to the enforcement of this chapter.
Report of Inspection. During a grocery store or restaurant inspection, the Department shall:
Record the inspection results on an inspection form provided by the Department;
Identify on the inspection form the conditions found that violate the provisions of this chapter;
Notify the grocery store or restaurant operator on the inspection form to correct violations by a specific date;
Provide one copy of the inspection report to the grocery store or restaurant operator; and
Provide one copy of the inspection report to MIEMSS.
The completed inspection report is a public document that is available for public disclosure in accordance with General Provisions Article, §§4-101—4-601, Annotated Code of Maryland.
